description: Introduces the basic terminology, concepts, and standards underlying financial accounting systems. Concepts will include revenue and expense recognition, accounts receivable, inventory, long-lived assets, liquidity and solvency. Explores the income statement, balance sheet, and statement of cash flows, often using reports filed by publicly-traded companies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Financial Accounting
subject: ACCT

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AFAM

description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Television and Crime
subject: AFAM

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from sites, room and board costs in sites, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: AFST

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AMST

description: This course is designed to introduce students to the vibrant field of Native American and Indigenous Literature and Critical Theory. The course will survey the long history of literature in the Americas (pre-Columbian to present), but it will focus mostly on recent and contemporary native literature in North America. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Native American Literatures
subject: AMST

description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States.  Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Inequality in America
subject: AMST

description: Offered in China. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. The course is open to Yale students and other IARU members only. Memory powerfully shapes our understanding of our lives. In this course, we will examine how photographic images equally powerfully shape our memory. We will read some of the key concepts of several thinkers who have taken individual and collective memory as their subject, such as Jacques Derrida, Benedict Anderson, Maurice Halbwachs and Marianne Hirsch. Additionally, we will study some of the great writers on photography, such as Susan Sontag, John Berger, Walter Benjamin, Allan Sekula and Roland Barthes. At the same time we will also explore what we can learn about memory from photographs, digital photographs, and photographic memorials, from the 1830s to the present. These photographs can be anonymous or famous, historical or recent. Our interest will not be simply in what makes them great images, but also in what makes them greatly influential in our lives. We will have class discussions as well as lectures, and students will be expected to bring photographs to share with the class. There will also be two field trips to photographic galleries in Beijing. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: July 4 - July 29.
title: Photography, History, and Memory
subject: AMST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: AMST

description: Introduces students to integral themes of archaeology to include: theoretical background; evolving intellectual traditions that have influenced the current state of the discipline; excavation, survey, and material analysis techniques and practice. Case studies from around the world will be incorporated into the material. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Archaeology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to the theories and debates within medical anthropology. Students will think critically about the terms body, health, and medicine. Topics will include: cross-cultural understandings of health; biomedicine and health regimes as culturally contingent; embodiment of difference including race, gender, and sexuality; bio-politics; and global and public health paradigms. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Forensic Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Why do we have sex? Sex has been a central concern to anthropologists since the very founding of the discipline in the late 19th century. This course analyzes the various aspects of sex from the perspective of sociocultural anthropology and linguistic anthropology. Topics include: sexual morphology and behavior; constructions of sex and gender; gendered violence, power, and language; and kinship and mating. Course readings will draw broadly from both historical and contemporary work within the broad discipline of anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Anthropological Approaches to Sex
subject: ANTH

description: This course is part of the IARU Global Summer Program. This course is open to Yale students and other IARU members only. The challenges of the 21st century in protecting the tangible and intangible, cultural and natural heritage of the world are global in character and need to be also addressed on a global level. Cultural and natural heritage are increasingly threatened with destruction not only by the traditional causes of decay, but also by changing social and economic conditions. For example, in the last years we have seen the phenomena of cultural cleansing rising in the Middle East and Africa, while natural disasters have taken a toll and underlined the need to develop sustainable and global strategies for preservation. This course offers an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the complex factors that challenge the preservation of cultural heritage. Guest speakers with relevant expertise will be invited to participate in many of the class sessions. In addition, the course will draw on the collections of the Yale University Museums for discussion and as the basis of student assignments. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Sustainable Preservation of Cultural Heritage: An Introduction to a Global Challenge of Our Time
subject: ANTH

description: This course explores historical and contemporary movements of people, goods, money, and imaginaries that have shaped the region of Asia. Based on central concerns of anthropology with culture, history, and power, we will approach "markets" and "capital" as meaningful processes of identity and place making. From early trading empires to present-day cosmopolitan hubs, we will examine commodity and financial flows, urbanization and globalization, consumer desires and popular cultures, with as much appreciation for difference as similarity across the Asian region and beyond. Case studies include the stock exchange in Shanghai, the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo, clothing marketplace in Ho Chi Minh City, sexual commerce in Mumbai, and city branding of Dubai. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Cultures and Markets in Asia
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Singapore. This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. Southeast Asia in Context is a five-week thematically based exploration of Southeast Asia's geographical and cultural diversity, which takes advantage of Singapore's position and character as a microcosm of this diversity. Blending classroom instruction on NUS Kent Ridge campus with hands-on fieldwork in Singapore, Cambodia and Thailand, SEA in Context offers modules on Southeast Asia with anthropological, historical and archaeological concentrations. The core module, "SE2222: Southeast Asia In Context" provides a broad overview of Southeast Asia from a historical, sociological and anthropological perspective. Its partner module, "SE2880A: Southeast Asia's Cultural Mosaic", will equip students with the analytical tools for the comparative study of society and culture, and features a 10-day field trip to various religious, cultural and archaeological sites in Cambodia and Thailand. Both modules deploy 'context-based' learning by combining in-class instruction at NUS campus with local and regional hands-on experience of Southeast Asian life. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition: $4,900. Course dates: June 18 - July 23.
title: Southeast Asia in Context
subject: ANTH

description: The sociocultural dimensions of inequality in the contemporary United States.  Readings draw on work in anthropology, sociology, economics, history, cultural studies, and investigative journalism to examine how neoliberal policies, exacerbated by the Great Recession, impact Americans divided by identity categories such as race, class, gender, and citizenship. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Inequality in America
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Tokyo. Animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in twentieth-century Japan. Focus on the social and historical context of the production and consumption of manga and anime. Explore gender and sexuality through these media and in Japanese popular culture. Create your own anime or manga short. No knowledge of Japanese required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Japan, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: May 28 - July 2.
title: Japanimation and Manga
subject: ANTH

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: APHY

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: APHY

description: The course will introduce the engineering and applied science student to multivariable calculus for use in solving problems of physical interest. The course will focus on topics including three-dimensional spaces and vectors, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus including Greens', Stokes' and the divergence theorems. Prerequisite: MATH 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: MultivariableCalculusEngineers
subject: APHY

description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
subject: APHY

description: First part of an intensive language course in New Haven and Morocco. Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from site, room and board costs at site, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S140. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic I
subject: ARBC

description: Second part of an intensive language course in New Haven and Morocco. Continuation of ARBC S130. Intensive review of grammar; readings from contemporary and classical Arab authors with emphasis on serial reading of unvoweled Arabic texts, prose composition, and formal conversation. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from site, room and board costs at site, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with ARBC S130. Prerequisite: ARBC 120 or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic II
subject: ARBC

description: Introduction to the world of the ancient mariners, with special attention to new discoveries and interpretations. The history and methodological development of maritime archaeology through art, texts, and underwater and land archaeology for ancient ships, particularly from pharaonic Egypt, the Bronze Aegean, and the Classical Mediterranean. The course concludes with discussion of the ethical and legal dimensions of the discipline. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Ancient Ships and Maritime Archaeology
subject: ARCG

description: An introduction to the language of visual expression, using studio projects to explore the fundamental principles of visual art. Students acquire a working knowledge of visual syntax applicable to the study of art history, popular culture, and art. Projects address all four major concentrations (graphic design, printing/printmaking, photography, and sculpture). 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Visual Thinking
subject: ART

description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Basic Drawing
subject: ART

description: An introduction to basic painting issues, stressing a beginning command of the conventions of pictorial space and the language of color. Class assignments and individual projects explore technical, conceptual, and historical issues central to the language of painting. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Painting Basics
subject: ART

description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Digital Photography
subject: ART

description: Interactive design explored through the development of projects that are based online. Concepts of prompt, feedback, and variable conditions; Web-specific design issues such as navigation and pacing, as well as design for variable sizes and devices; best practices in code craft and design. The Web as a social ecosystem in which time and performance play important roles. Instruction in HTML, CSS, and some Javascript. No prior programming experience required. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Interactive Design: WWW
subject: ART

description: Introduction to the principals, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in 20th and 21st Century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principals of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,950. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Principles of Animation
subject: ART

description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Galaxies and the Universe
subject: ASTR

description: Offered Online. An introduction to how celestial patterns and events were observed and interpreted up to the Copernican revolution. Ancient observatories, calendar systems, records of astronomical events, and the role of astronomical knowledge in culture. Exercises in naked-eye observation of the sky. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Archaeoastronomy
subject: ASTR

description: Introduction to the study of life at the molecular level and to cell biology and membrane physiology. Topics include the three-dimensional structures and function of large biological molecules, the human genome, the design of antiviral drugs to treat HIV/AIDS, organization and functional properties of biological membranes, membrane physiology and signaling, rough endoplasmic reticulum and synthesis of membrane/secretory membrane proteins, endocytosis, the cytoskeleton, and cell division. Covers the material of BIOL 101 and 102, the first half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Followed in the summer by BIOL S106. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Biochemistry, Biophysics, and Cell Biology
subject: BIOL

description: Introduction to genes, genetics, developmental biology, ecology, evolutionary biology, animal behavior, and the history of life. How genes control development and disease; Mendel's rules; examples of organ physiology; evolutionary transitions and natural selection; adaptation at genic, chromosomal, cellular, organismal, and supra-organismal levels; distributional and social consequences of particular suites of organismal adaptations. Covers the material of BIOL 103 and 104, the second half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL S105. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Genes, Ecology, and Evolutionary Biology
subject: BIOL

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sample size estimation, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package.
Enrollment limited to students in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. and Accelerated M.B.A./M.P.H. programs; not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program or the five-year B.A.-B.S./M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Biostatistics
subject: BIS

description: This course will focus on the history of gardens, landscape parks, and the architecture of country houses in Great Britain from 1500 to 1750. During this period Britain experienced significant political, economic, and social change. Absolutist monarchical rule gave way after the English Civil War ( 1642-1651 ) and the Glorious Revolution,
requirements: ( 1668 ), to a constitutional monarchy subordinate to parliamentary government controlled in large part by the landed gentry. Centuries-old customs of landowners sharing common ground for grazing rights with local farmers, known as the open-field system, and respecting the boundaries of contiguous small farms gave way with the implementation of the Enclosure Acts, which allowed the landed gentry and landed aristocracy to remove villages, buy out contiguous farms, and annex commons to empark their estates. And the landed aristocracy in their country estates established seats of power which they made manifest in the design, scale, and expense of their gardens and the architecture of their houses.
title: History of British Gardens, Landscape Parks, and Country House Architecture, 1500 to 1750
subject: BRST

description: A selection of Victorian texts offering a broad view of period life and culture. Emphasis on novels that show "outsiders" adjusting to the complexities of urban and rural life in nineteenth-century England. Study of the orphan, alien, disoriented, or alienated characters who find a place in society through art, intellectual enterprise, or spiritual enlightenment.
title: Victorian Fiction
subject: BRST

description: A detailed study of representative works of modern British drama, based on current productions on the London stage. Theatrical conventions developed by playwrights and actors in the theater of postwar Britain, both on the fringe and in the mainstream of the West End. Attention to social issues addressed by the plays.
title: Modern British Drama
subject: BRST

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Soc&BehavFoundof Health: Accl Soc&BehavFoundof Health
subject: CDE

description:
This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive overview of epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurements of disease frequency and association, study design (including randomized and non-randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecologic studies), screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
subject: CDE

description: Analysis of equilibrium systems. Topics include energy conservation, entropy, heat engines, Legendre transforms, derived thermodynamic potentials and equilibrium criteria, multicomponent systems, chemical reaction and phase equilibria, systematic derivation of thermodynamic identities, criteria for thermodynamic stability, and introduction to statistical thermodynamics. Prerequisite: MATH 120 or ENAS 151 or permission of instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Chem Eng Thermodynamics
subject: CENG

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30234) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30235).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: CGSC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30234) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30235).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: CGSC

description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: Mental Lives of Babies and An...
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
subject: CGSC

description: Chemistry studied in the context of major contemporary issues, such as climate change, environmental degradation, renewable energy, and pharmaceutical developments. This course takes an interactive approach to learning chemistry with demonstrations and hands-on experience. Activities will highlight chemical reactions in fuel cells, properties of acid rain, nylon production, radioactivity, and more. Does not satisfy premedical chemistry requirements or requirements for the Chemistry major. Not open to students who have completed another chemistry course at Yale. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Chemistry in Context
subject: CHEM

description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive, inorganic, and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session A: stoichiometry, atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular structure, gas laws, properties of solutions. These courses (CHEM S161/S165) with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Corresponding laboratories will not be offered this summer. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: General Chemistry I
subject: CHEM

description: A comprehensive survey of modern descriptive inorganic and physical chemistry, intended for students with high school preparation in chemistry. Session B: chemical kinetics and thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, acid-base theory, electrochemistry, transition metal chemistry, introduction to organic chemistry. Prerequisite: CHEM S161. These courses (CHEM S161/165) with laboratories, meet departmental requirements for the major and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Corresponding laboratories will not be offered this summer. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: General Chemistry II
subject: CHEM

description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session A: structure and bonding, chemical energetics, stereochemistry, alkanes, nucleophilic substitution, infrared spectroscopy, alkenes and alkynes, alcohols and ethers. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Corresponding laboratories will not be offered this summer. For college students and beyond. After college-level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Organic Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: The fundamental principles of organic chemistry. Session B: aldehydes and ketones, strategies in organic synthesis, carboxylic acid derivatives, carbonyl condensation reactions, sulfur and phosphorus compounds, bifunctional molecules, carbohydrates, organic nitrogen compounds, amino acids and proteins. These courses (CHEM S220/S221), with laboratories, satisfy departmental requirements for the major, and are appropriate for students seeking to fulfill medical school requirements. Corresponding laboratories will not be offered this summer. For college students and beyond. After college-level general chemistry. Students wishing to take only the first or second of these courses must obtain the permission of the Director of Summer Sciences. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Organic Chemistry
subject: CHEM

description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Autism and Related Disorders
subject: CHLD

description: Exploration of imagery of myths on Greek works of art and architecture ranging from great temples such as the Parthenon to small objects such as painted posts. Course includes visits to Yale's collection. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
subject: CLCV

description: An exploration of the myriad ways in which law and technology intersect, with a special focus on broadband, the internet, and how telecommunications law has evolved to where it is today. Topics include the breakup of the Bell system monopoly, Wi-Fi, FCC regulation of broadband and the Internet, voice-over Internet protocol, smartphones, and mobile networks. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30-July 1.
title: Internet and Telecommunications Law
subject: CPSC

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: June 27 - July 29.
title: In Prague Film and Fiction
subject: CZEC

description: Designed to introduce practical tools for directing, this course applies to anyone who is interested in working on technique as a director, whether as a career, for teachers directing a school play or for community theater productions. Topics include dramaturgy, script analysis, the director's work with the script, working with the actor, voice and speech techniques, and stage management organization. No formal training in directing necessary. Applicants should send a brief statement describing their background and areas of interest. A transcript is not required. Limited housing is available for this course; contact Yale Summer Session at 203.432.2430 for details. Students must be available from 9:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday through Friday as well as Saturday afternoons and evenings and Sunday morning and afternoon. This intense course requires a full commitment of the student's time. The faculty reserves the right to add, extend, or adjust scheduled hours to accommodate the progress of the class. For college students and beyond. Tuition: $750. Dates: July 14 - 23.
title: A Practical Approach to Directing
subject: DIR

description: Exploration and development of the fundamentals of the actor's craft based on the principles of Stanislavski. The course is actually a concise training program in which each student takes more than one class. The classes are in the following areas: (1) play analysis class, to understand what is to be acted; (2) acting class, to learn the application of basic acting techniques; (3) vocal production class, to improve vocal and articulation skills; (4) improvisation and mask class, to help free the imagination and to build confidence in spontaneous self-expression; (5) movement class, to strengthen the body and to encourage the use of the body for emotional expression; and (6) scene study class, to understand how the classes listed above come together when working on a scene. The instructors constitute a teaching staff of working professionals and are assisted by teaching associates giving the students individual attention. The summer drama program requires a full commitment of the student's time. Classes are held in the mornings, afternoons, and two evenings each week, Monday through Friday, with 26 to 28 classroom hours each week, 4 to 6 library hours each week, plus additional hours for individual tutorials and scheduled rehearsal time. Extra evening and Saturday morning sessions may be scheduled for group activities and additional classes. A single grade will be awarded for the course. Enrollment is limited. Complete applications must include a resume of relevant experience and a letter of recommendation from a drama teacher or other theater professional. Application deadline: May 1. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Yale Summer Conservatory for Actors
subject: DRMA

description: This course offers a survey of girls' comics, or shojo manga, in Japan. We will discuss major historical trends, read works by important artists, watch adaptations (including anime and live-action TV series/films) and analyze gender and sexuality within the texts as well as in the manga industry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Girls' Manga and Gender/Sexuality in Japan
subject: EALL

description: Introduction to modern theories of decision-making under uncertainty by investors in financial markets. Analysis of expected utility theory and the Allais paradox, subjective expected utility and the Ellsberg paradox, portfolio theory, efficient markets, APT and behavioral economics. Prerequisites: ECON 115 and MATH 115 or their equivalents or scores of 5 on both AP Microeconomics and AP BC Calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Finance
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30039) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30040).
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Introduction to the principles of microeconomics, supply and demand, consumer theory, and competitive markets. Applications to contemporary policy issues such as rent control, minimum wage, antitrust policy, pollution, and income inequality. For college students and beyond. May not be taken after ECON 108 or 110. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30039) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30040).
title: Introduction to Microeconomics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30043) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30042).
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to basic macroeconomic concepts and theories, such as national income accounting, theories of growth, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policy, banking, finance, and economic crises, with special emphasis on the recent financial crisis. Prerequisite: ECON 108, 110, 115 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30043) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30042).
title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluating quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30044) and Session B: July 2 - August 5 (CRN 30045).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Basic probability theory, statistics, and linear regression. Methods of evaluating quantitative information; the use of data to answer quantitative questions in the social sciences. After introductory microeconomics and MATH 112 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30044) and Session B: July 2 - August 5 (CRN 30045).
title: Econometrics and Data Analysis I
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to the theory of multiperson decision problems and its application in economic analysis. Discussion of static and dynamic noncooperative games with particular attention to the notions of Nash equilibrium and sub-game perfect equilibrium. Prerequisite: two terms of introductory economics (ECON 115 and 116 or the equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Game Theory
subject: ECON

description: This course will develop techniques used in finance. Investment securities, options, risk, and portfolio selection will be studied. Through problem sets, quizzes, and class examples students will apply knowledge of financial concepts. Prerequisite: ECON 115 or equivalent. No prior knowledge of finance is required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Corporate Finance
subject: ECON

description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. The organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. Substantive theoretical component and practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: MATH 112, ECON 121, or permission of instructor. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition: $7,300. Course Dates: June 20 - July 22.
title: Private Law and Contract Enforcement in the United States and France
subject: ECON

description: Offered Online. Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. Corruption occurs where fundamental institutions are weak or poorly designed, while situation-specific incentives make corruption tempting, and personal ethics are malleable. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. This summer, the textbook and the course materials have been updated. For college students and beyond. Prerequisite: ECON , 110, or 115, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Causes and Consequences of Corruption
subject: ECON

description: This is a course on efficiency. We focus on the First and Second Welfare Theorems in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures (e.g., where welfare theorems do not hold) considering externalities, public goods, and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Efficiency and Equity in Public Policy
subject: ECON

description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Topics in International Economics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary circuits and computer logic; sensors and actuators; signal processing and design for data transmission; information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using MATLAB. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Digital Information Age
subject: EENG

description: An exploration of the scientific basis, and inaccuracies, of modern science fiction. Technologies explored include nanotechnology, the theory of relativity, information technology, and environmental sustainability and terraforming. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Science of Science Fiction
subject: EENG

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: ENAS

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to the MATLAB and C programming languages for solving a variety of problems encountered in engineering, mathematics, and the natural sciences. General programming techniques, data analysis, numerical simulations, and transmission of data files between programs. Projects include processing microphone speech and digital images. Prerequisites: Math 115 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: previous programming experience. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Computing for Engineers & Scientists
subject: ENAS

description: The course will introduce the engineering and applied science student to multivariable calculus for use in solving problems of physical interest. The course will focus on topics including three-dimensional spaces and vectors, vector-valued functions, partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus including Greens', Stokes' and the divergence theorems. Prerequisite: MATH 115 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Multivariable Calculus for Engineers
subject: ENAS

description: Basic theory of ordinary and partial differential equations useful in applications. First- and second-order equations, separation of variables, power series solutions, Fourier series, Laplace transforms. Prerequisites: ENAS 151 or equivalent and knowledge of matrix-based operations. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Ordinary and Partial Differential Equations with Applications
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN: 30052) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN: 30053).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 12. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN: 30052) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN: 30053).
title: Writing Seminars I
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professional strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, N. Scott Momaday, George Orwell, Brent Staples, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, and Alice Walker. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
subject: ENGL

description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is “what do we mean when we say ‘American?’” Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by “literature,” so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one’s own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Readings in American Literature
subject: ENGL

description: Fundamentals of the craft of fiction writing explored through readings from classic and contemporary short stories and novels. Focus on how each author has used the fundamentals of craft. Writing exercises emphasize elements such as voice, structure, point of view, character, and tone. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Reading Fiction for Craft
subject: ENGL

description: Conducted as a workshop, this course offers students the opportunity to write fiction and the particular sort of nonfiction that reflects and explores the narrative of their own lives. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling, among them, character, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students may concentrate on a single genre, or, if they wish, experiment with both. Readings will include selections from contemporary American fiction and creative nonfiction. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with the online application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Writing Fiction and Creative Nonfiction
subject: ENGL

description: Love, sex, gender, society, and theater practice in Shakespeare's comic genres, from the early farces and romantic comedies to the problem plays and late romances. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Romances
subject: ENGL

description: Study of three histories and seven tragedies at the pinnacle of Shakespeare's career. Focus on the source of each play's pathos and the nature of its poetic sublimity; some attention to performance and to the relation between the genres of history and tragedy. Extensive practice in writing short and medium-length critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read Julius Caesar. (The Signet edition, ordered through The Yale Bookstore, is preferred, but the Norton genre volumes are especially handsome substitutions; the Arden single play editions are more than acceptable if their price is not intimidating.) The regular course meetings will be supplemented by six evening screenings, and students are required to attend at least four of these. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Shakespeare: Histories and Tragedies
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. A study of Milton's major poetry, with attention to his relation to the cultural, social, and political struggles of the Puritan Revolution. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures, and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1875 requirement. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Milton
subject: ENGL

description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: ENGL

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Examines travel writing, surveying a wide range of works, from long-form place essays to destination articles, from travel memoir to adventure odysseys. Readings include, Paul Theroux, Ryszard Kapuscinski, Jan Morris, and Pico Iyer. How voyages lend travel writers structure: a natural beginning, middle, and end. Students are encouraged to take advantage of their geographic mobility for their assignments and tasked to find an innovative mode or vehicle of exploring their chosen place. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: May 30 - June 24.
title: Travel Writing
subject: ENGL

description: Survey of the modern movement in Western European literature and art from the mid-nineteenth century to the mid-twentieth century. Writers include Baudelair, Ibsen, Wilde, Yeats, H.D., Pound, Stein, Eliot, Mann, Proust, Joyce, Woolf, Pirandello, and Beckett. Consideration of movements in the visual arts from impressionism to surrealism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Modernism Literature & Arts
subject: ENGL

description: Offered Online. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: ENGL

description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2013 and 2014. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Theater Now
subject: ENGL

description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Investigative Journalism
subject: ENGL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: EP&E

description: Offered online. Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Green Energy Systems
subject: EVST

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: EVST

description: Sustainable development as it relates to institutional change, decision-making processes, and systems thinking. Throughout the course we will explore the question of how organizations have the capacity to advance principles of sustainable development in their operational functions, mission and growth. The students will engage with Yale as a Living Laboratory throughout the course as well as visit one to two peer institutions in the region. Course lectures and discussions will draw from Yale's sustainability commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, implement a transportation demand management system, serve sustainable and local food in the residential colleges, build sustainable buildings, integrate sustainability into the master plan framework, reduce waste, and manage the urban campus via an ecosystem services framework. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Sustainability and Institutions
subject: EVST

description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Global Environmental Governance
subject: EVST

description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Global Environmental Governance
subject: F&ES

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum. Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students choose either FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. or further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: June 27 - July 29.
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Paris, France. Introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth and consumerism of Paris. Explores Parisian neighborhoods on city walks and visits two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinematheque Francaise and the Institut Lumiere). Films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amelie. All readings will be in English with further optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Paris and the Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: FILM

description: A study of the interrelations among popular sport, cinema, television, radio, print, and social media. Explores topics of identity, commerce, and civics through contemporary texts (Hunger Games, Senna, Invictus), and introduces the history of sport in media culture. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Sports and Media
subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Swaziland. Explores the intersection of global health and visual media. Focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience and create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: June 27-August 5.
title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Television and Crime
subject: FILM

description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed; how it influenced America; and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Television Situation Comedy
subject: FILM

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 5 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,750. Course dates: May 30 - July 29.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French I
subject: FREN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 5 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. Focuses on developing language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in un-simplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S110. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,750. Course dates: May 30 - July 29.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French II
subject: FREN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Priority is given to Yale students. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. Credit only on completion of FREN S140. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Intermediate and Advanced French I
subject: FREN

An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. subject: FREN

Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 23 - June 24.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings; discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals; films; songs; stories; and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 23 - June 24.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit.
