subject: FREN

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: G&G

description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: GLBL

description: Explores the evolution of the international balance of power since the outset of the twentieth century. The causes and conduct of World Wars I and II and the Cold War, as well as the evolution of international politics since the demise of the Soviet Union. Emphasis is both analytical and historical. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Balance of Power: Theory and Practice
subject: GLBL

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
subject: GLBL

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from sites, room and board costs in sites, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: GLBL

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Credit only on completion of GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 30-July 22.

subject: GMAN

subject: GMAN

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - August 1.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: GMAN

description: The complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. Brings together two periods of psychological approaches on beauty and the arts: discussions of psychology of the arts in 18th century England, Germany and France with the 20th century discussions from Freud and Lacan to empirical psychology. Theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner), painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff) literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Psychological Disciplines and the Arts
subject: GMAN

description: Offered online. Students acquire skills for reading German-language texts of any difficulty with some fluency. Study of syntax and grammar; practice in close reading and translation of texts in different genres in the humanities. For Yale graduate students only. Session A: May 23 - June 24.
title: German for Reading
subject: GMAN

description: An introduction to the history of the American Revolution, focusing on the diverse experiences of ordinary people. Topics include slavery, popular politics and protest, Loyalism, Native Americans and women in the Revolution, society and war, and the popular memory of the Revolution. Students will write a short research paper based on eighteenth-century sources in Yale archives. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: The American Revolution
subject: HIST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of fiction and nonfiction features. Topics will include: the Progressive Era, Jazz Age urban America, the Great Depression, World War II, the Cold War, Watergate, Vietnam, September 11th, and the 2008 financial crisis. Emphasis will be placed on the manner in which the past is depicted in individual films and what the choice of subjects reveals about the directors' sociopolitical moment. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. In-class screenings will include films such as The Birth of a Nation, Gold Diggers of 1933, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Apocalypse Now, Wall Street, United 93, Inglourious Basterds, and Capitalism: A Love Story. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: HIST

description: Offered in the Beinecke Rare Book Library. The social, cultural, and technological aspects of book publishing, production, and distribution from the fifteenth century to the present. Emphasis on three critical eras and technologies: the Renaissance and the hand-press book, the nineteenth century and the rise of mechanized printing and mass distribution, and the current digital age, when long-held assumptions about books, publishing, and reading will be examined and far-reaching questions about literacy, distribution, global access and equity, and even cognitive science discussed. The course is taught as a seminar through a series of firsthand encounters with manuscripts, rare books, prints, and other primary sources, from the medieval period through the present day. In addition, several class meetings will take place in other Yale collections that contain objects related to our study of the book as an instrument and agent of social change. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: From Gutenberg to Google Books: The Cultural History of Publishing, 1450 to the Present
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. subject: HIST

description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
subject: HIST

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,650. Course dates: July 4-August 5.
title: History of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: This course will explore the history of modern Latin America from the independence movements of the early nineteenth century to the present. Students examine a combination of primary documents and significant secondary works to gain an introduction to the major themes and debates of this field. Students learn to critically analyze these textual materials and discuss their ideas with one another in a seminar setting. Students who have taken History 355 Colonial Latin America are especially encouraged to enroll. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Modern Latin America
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Swaziland. Explores the intersection of global health and visual media. Focuses on global health issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and violence in public health. Students learn filmmaking as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience and create a short film on a selected global health topic. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Swaziland, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: June 27-August 5.
title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: HLTH

description: An introduction to Western art of the Baroque through Modern periods (17th-20th centuries). Through a series of case studies of individual artworks, we will explore how painting negotiates two fundamental antipodes of human experience: sex and death. Themes include: seduction and castration motif, the "vulgar" sensuality of the Rococo, murder and the Modern image, and Primitivist fantasies of female sexuality, among others. Artists include: Caravaggio, Gentileschi, Poussin, Rembrandt, Chardin, Fragonard, David, Gericault, Courbet, Cezanne, Gauguin, and Picasso. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: An Introduction to Sex and De...
title: An Introduction to Sex and Death in Western Art
subject: HSAR

description: Exploration of imagery of myths on Greek works of art and architecture ranging from great temples such as the Parthenon to small objects such as painted posts. Course includes visits to Yale's collection. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
title: Art and Myth in Ancient Greece
subject: HSAR

description: An introduction to postwar art by way of its engagement with communication technologies. Topics will include Pop Art, Conceptual Art, video art, and performance. A strong focus will be placed upon artists' use of media to question dominant narratives around gender, race, and sexuality, especially the ways in which artists engage media's vocabulary to interrupt hegemonic narratives. Frequent visits to Yale's galleries and facilities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
short_title: Medium and Media in Modern Art
title: Medium and Media in Modern Art
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: HSAR

description: This course explores how the borders, boundaries, and demarcations between drug categories, such as licit and illicit, have been established, contested, and shifted in the United States throughout the twentieth century. We will explore how drug categories have reflected the values of those who made them and affected the lives of those who use drugs.

title: The History of Drugs in Twentieth-Century America

description: Offered Online. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Friends
subject: HUMS

description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a l- or 2-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department. Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Critically examines the cultural identity of Tuscany, as manifested in its history, art, architecture, and folklore, with a special focus on Siena. Literary and historical readings, cinematic representations of Tuscany, in-depth tours of the city's monuments and museums, as well as field trips to Florence, San Gimignano, Pisa, and the Tuscan countryside. Particular attention will be devoted to the defining ritual of Sienese life: Il Palio, the splendid medieval horse race run in the city's central Piazza del Campo. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. Tuition: see ITAL S130/S140. Course dates: June 22 - July 25.
title: History, Culture, and Film in Tuscany
subject: ITAL

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. Focus on the long-standing rivalry between the two cities of Tuscany, Florence, and Siena, their wars, their politics, and cultural competitiveness. Examination of the works of Florentine writers (Dante, Petrarch, and Boccaccio) directed against the life and history of Siena, and the angry verses of the Sienese poet Cecco Angiolieri, along with the writings of Catherine of Siena. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from the site, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition: see ITAL S110-S120. Course dates: June 22 - July 25.
short_title: Tale of Two Cities: The Myth ...
title: Tale of Two Cities: The Myth of Florence and Siena
subject: ITAL

description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. Credit only on completion of LATN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Grammar
subject: LATN

description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: LATN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of twelfth- and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. The role of Paris in the works of writers such as Joyce, Hemingway, Colette, and Breton. How the situation of the artist as expatriate or exile affects what can be written. Iconoclasts of experimental language who found a congenial home in Paris, including Gertrude Stein and the surrealists. Works of expatriate British and American writers examined in relation to works by contemporary French authors. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from site, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Paris in the 1920s
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey D'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: May 30 - July 1.
title: Belle Époque France
subject: LITR

description: The complex function and effects of the aesthetical regime. Brings together two periods of psychological approaches on beauty and the arts: discussions of psychology of the arts in 18th-century England, Germany, and France with the 20th-century discussions from Freud and Lacan to empirical psychology. Theoretical texts (including Freud, Jung, Fechner), painting (from Raffaello to Dali), photography (from Man Ray to Jeanloup Sieff), literature (from Rousseau to Doeblin), as well as opera and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Psychological Disciplines and the Arts
subject: LITR

description: With a focus on texts that were originally written in Old Irish and Middle Welsh, this class offers an introduction to medieval Celtic literature in translation. The class will examine the most colorful Celtic texts: those concerning magic, the supernatural, and the Otherworld. By the end of the course students will have a firm grasp of the context in which the texts were produced, and will be in a position to interpret the unique symbology of Celtic literature. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Celtic Magic
subject: LITR

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - August 1.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: LITR

description: Examines the problem of evil in three major literary texts from the Renaissance to our own time: Milton's Paradise Lost, Shelley's Frankenstein, Rushdie's Satanic Verses. How the idea of an omniscient, benevolent god can coexist with the presence of suffering in the world; whether evil exists or whether it is an aspect of human behavior and choice; and what we can do to train ourselves to combat evil and suffering. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: The Problem of Evil
subject: LITR

description: Offered Online. Limits and their properties. Definitions and some techniques of differentiation and the evaluation of definite integrals, with applications. Use of the software package Mathematica to illustrate concepts. No prior acquaintance with calculus or computing assumed. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
subject: MATH

description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
subject: MATH

description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
subject: MATH

description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,875. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cell, and Developmental Biology
subject: MCDB

description: A comprehensive course in cellular and molecular biology. Emphasis on general principles of cell function and rationale and design of pertinent biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Cell Biology
subject: MCDB

description: An introduction to the biochemistry of animals, plants, and microorganisms, emphasizing the relations of chemical principles and structure to the evolution and regulation of living systems. This course will be taught in an active learning format, whereby the typical lecture and homework elements of a course are reversed. Narrated Powerpoint video lectures are viewed by students at home before the class session, while in-class time is devoted to problem-solving exercises, collaborative projects and discussions.
requirements: BIOL 101, 102, 103, and 104 or MCDB 120 or MCDB 200; one term of organic chemistry
title: Biochemistry
subject: MCDB

description: Introduction to neuroscience, divided into 3 course modules: 1) Cellular neurophysiology, addressing the excitable properties of neurons and the function of synapses, 2) Systems neurobiology, examining neural circuits as they relate to the functional properties of the nervous system, with each system that is addressed examined in detail, and 3) Neural development and plasticity, examining the cellular and molecular mechanisms governing neural development, plasticity, and the establishment of memory. Prerequisites: introductory course in biology (BIOL 101-104) and at least 1 semester of college chemistry, or permission of instructor. A course in physics or its equivalent is also recommended but not required. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Neurobiology
subject: MCDB

description: This course will provide an introduction to materials science for both engineering and science majors. The first half of the class will introduce basic topics including atomic and molecular bonding, crystal structure, deformation, and stress, strain, and failure. The second half of the course will cover a selection of materials, including metals, ceramics, polymers, emulsions, and dispersions. Emphasis will be placed on "soft materials" that dominate our daily experiences with food, pharmaceuticals, personal care products, and even biological materials. Prerequisites: college-level introductory courses or equivalents in calculus, physics, and chemistry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Materials Science
subject: MENG

description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Islam
subject: MMES

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: MMES

description: The development of both theocratic and democratic ideals in modern Islamic political thought and the development of regimes of government in Muslim countries since the nineteenth century. Early constitutional movements, the rise of political Islam, the management of religion in various twentieth-century states, the Iranian revolution, and the growth of Salafi ideas, culminating in the ISIS caliphate. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Islam&DemocracyModMiddleEast
subject: MMES

description: Offered Online. The changing meaning of the term "genius" from ancient Greece to the present. The nature of genius examined through the lives and working methods of exceptional individuals, including Mozart, da Vinci, Newton, Picasso, and Joyce. Topics such as nature vs. nurture, prodigy, concentration, memory, and exceptional processing skills explored to define and establish markers for genius. Recent developments in neurobiology that may elucidate why some individuals possess extraordinary mental and artistic abilities. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Brains of Genius: Mozart & Friends
subject: MUSI

description: Offered Online. The developmental history of technology in music creativity, with particular attention to the aesthetics and musical invention in the genres and repertoire of electronic dance music including: house, techno, trance, hip-hop, jungle, drum 'n' bass, dub step, drum step and trap, among others. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: EDM: Fundamentals
subject: MUSI

description: Introduction to the world of the ancient mariners, with special attention to new discoveries and interpretations. The history and methodological development of maritime archaeology through art, texts, and underwater and land archaeology for ancient ships, particularly from pharaonic Egypt, the Bronze Age Aegean, and the Classical Mediterranean. The course concludes with discussion of the ethical and legal dimensions of the discipline. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Ancient Ships and Maritime Archaeology
subject: NELC

description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonial Nahuatl. Beginning-, intermediate-, and advanced-level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual practice sessions and group cultural activities. Partial scholarships are available. Details on the Yale Latin American Iberian Studies website, . Open to undergraduate and graduate students. 3 Credits. Tuition $6,000. Program dates: June 27 - August 5.
title: Intensive Nahuatl Language and Culture
subject: NHTL

description: 4 credit hours. This course explores the multidisciplinary theoretical foundations that are the basis for community health nursing practice. Community health nurses provide preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitation, and hospice services across the life span. The clinical experience focuses on the delivery of these health services in community organizations. A community-as-partner assessment and diagnosis project, which culminates in identification of a community health problem and potential solutions, augments core seminar content. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
short_title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Co...
title: Sem in Comm Hlth Nur & PH: Comm Hlth Nurs & PH
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course focuses on clinical practice essential to nursing care of women, newborns, and their families throughout the childbearing cycle and the neonatal period. Clinical settings include hospital and ambulatory care. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Clinical Practice in Maternal-Newborn Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to the provision of nursing care to childbearing families throughout the childbearing cycle, the neonatal period, and the pre- and inter-conceptional phases. Application of the nursing process as it relates to the promotion, maintenance, and restoration of health is emphasized. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Maternal-Newborn Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. Utilizing a family-centered approach, this course provides clinical experience in identifying and assessing children's physiological and developmental needs, and planning, implementing, and evaluating a plan of nursing care to meet the needs of a particular child and his/her family in health care settings. Students have opportunities to use principles of growth and development, knowledge of the child's and family's physical and emotional responses to illness, and principles of pediatric nursing in caring for children and their families. The student gains skill and knowledge in the nursing role and an appreciation for the importance of utilizing research findings in practice and collaborating with other health professionals. This course is graded on a Pass/Fail basis only. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Clinical Practice in Pediatric Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course presents theory essential to promote health and adaptation to illness for children and their families. Emphasis is placed on growth and development, as well as pathophysiological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence children's and families' response to health and illness. Required of all students in the prespecialty year.
title: Seminar in Pediatric Nursing
subject: NURS

description: 1.5 credit hours. This course provides an overview of theoretical principles and concepts essential to assessing, designing, implementing, and evaluating population-based health projects within and across the health system and other organizations. In this course, students critically examine change, decision making, evaluation, and management-related theories as a foundation for project planning, implementation, and evaluation of an evidence-based improvement project. Students identify and develop a theory-based project derived from an integrated synthesis of the literature. Students also identify appropriate software, tools, and communication techniques essential for leading an interprofessional team from inception to completion of the project within and across health care systems or other organizations. The tools and processes learned in this course will support work toward the subsequent capstone experience. Taught as an intensive during the summer intersession. Required of D.N.P. students in the first year.
title: Thry & Applctn of Proj Mgmt
subject: NURS

description: 2 credit hours. This course provides a critical overview of the historical and contemporary health and health disparities research, relevant literature, and policies as essential context for understanding how to achieve health equity. The social and biological determinants of health and health disparities are also critically examined in light of political, economic, cultural, legal, and ethical issues. Selected health and health disparities population-based data are examined as a foundation for explicating how subpopulations experience disparate health across the life span. Students examine how past and current policies (state, federal, tribal), politics, population-based data findings, and selected frameworks enhance or act as barriers to achieving health equity with diverse populations, systems, and/or communities. Additionally, students design an organizational policy plan for achieving population health and health equity within a health system, organization, and/or community-based health system.
title: Achieving Population Health Equity
subject: NURS

description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea. Whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Happiness
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to the history and methods of philisophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: First-Order Logic
subject: PHIL

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30131) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30133).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PHIL

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30131) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30133).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to problems and methods in the philosophy of law. The nature of law and legal authority; political questions regarding the nature of rights and limitations on freedom; issues in criminal law, tort law, and contract law. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Eastern Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: PHIL

description: Examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited to 18 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: PHYS

description: Offered Online. A critical evaluation of Hollywood action movies, using the laws of physics and Fermi-type estimation techniques to distinguish between fictional and real movie physics. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Movie Physics
subject: PHYS

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Tours of energy facilities on the Yale campus. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. Enrollment limited to 28 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S150, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,875. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: General Physics Laboratory
subject: PHYS

description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S151, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students and beyond. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,875. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: General Physics Laboratory
subject: PHYS

description: An introduction to classical physics with special emphasis on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Topics include electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Essential calculus is introduced as needed. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: University Physics for the Life Sciences
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents. May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: University Physics
subject: PHYS

description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents. May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: University Physics
subject: PHYS

description: Explores the evolution of the international balance of power since the outset of the twentieth century. The causes and conduct of World Wars I and II and the Cold War, as well as the evolution of international politics since the demise of the Soviet Union. Emphasis is both analytical and historical. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Balance of Power: Theory and Practice
subject: PLSC

description: An examination of the causes of war, with an emphasis on strategic, social, symbolic, and reputational aspects. Topics will include: deterrence, honor, signaling, audience costs, and international law. Class time will consist of discussion, mini-lectures, and games. Readings will draw from a variety of sources, including game theory, statistical analyses of observational and experimental data, cultural and psychological approaches, history, and military strategy. The course will emphasize strategies to articulate theory in clear scientifically productive ways and to devise successful research designs that avoid the many possible pitfalls in social scientific inference. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Causes of War
subject: PLSC

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
subject: PLSC

description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and of the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: PLSC

description: Examines the norms or principles that establish and justify societies and determine the rights and responsibilities of a society in a globalized world. Students will analyze the responsibility of individuals in relation to each other and to society as a whole, and of a society in relation to other societies. This course will consider the application of these principles to such issues as justice, ethics, politics, and social institutions, in a world community.
short_title: The Economics and Ethics of G...
title: The Economics and Ethics of Globalization
subject: PLSC

description: The development of international environmental policy and the functioning of global environmental governance. Critical evaluation of theoretical claims in the literature and the reasoning of policy makers. Introduction of analytical and theoretical tools used to assess environmental problems. Case studies emphasize climate, forestry, and fisheries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Global Environmental Governance
subject: PLSC

description: This course is part of the IARU Global Summer Program. This course is open to Yale students and other IARU members only. Focus will be on bridging foreign decision-making theories and Chinese foreign policymaking practice to understand the major factors that shape Chinese foreign policy. These include the following: the impact of historical legacies, systematic constraints, personality and decision making style of paramount leaders, evolving foreign policy making structure and changing bureaucratic process, fluid domestic politics, and the impact of the military, nationalism, and public opinion on Chinese foreign policy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Understanding Chinese Foreign Policymaking
subject: PLSC

description: International human rights organizations and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: International Human Rights and Politics
subject: PLSC

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, as well as films and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Cold War
subject: PLSC

description: Public opinion in democratic societies. Voter ignorance, representation, elite manipulation of public opinion, and attitude formation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Public Opinion
subject: PLSC

description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Crime and Punishment
subject: PLSC

description: Offered Online. Intensive introduction to the written Constitution, revolving tightly around two books authored by the instructor--America's Constitution: A Biography (2005) and America's Unwritten Constitution: The Precedents and Principles We Live By (2012). Provides detailed knowledge of America's written Constitution and considers various techniques of constitutional interpretation. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Reading the Constitution
subject: PLSC

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: PLSC

description: The development of both theocratic and democratic ideals in modern Islamic political thought and the development of regimes of government in Muslim countries since the nineteenth century. Early constitutional movements, the rise of political Islam, the management of religion in various twentieth-century states, the Iranian revolution, and the growth of Salafi ideas, culminating in the ISIS caliphate. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Islam&DemocracyModMiddleEast
subject: PLSC

description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S122 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another romance language. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,900. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages I
subject: PORT

description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another romance language. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,900. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages II
subject: PORT

description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in English with sessions in Portuguese. An introduction to Brazilian cultural history from 1500 to the present. Essential themes and figures for understanding modern Brazil. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 for tuition. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Introduction to Brazil
subject: PORT

description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, and social bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Psychology
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Psychology
subject: PSYC

description: Introduction to major discoveries and theories of human emotion. Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Human Emotion
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. Covers the range of theoretical and empirical material that relates to the understanding of the criminal mind. Four main topics will be covered: personality and psychopathological factors associated with criminal behavior; theoretical and psychobiological explanations of crime; the interaction between biology and environment; the impact of psychobiological models for policy and intervention. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: The Criminal Mind
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Offered in both Session A: May 30 - July 1 (CRN 30130) and Session B: July 4 - August 5 (CRN 30132).
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. subject: PSYC

description: Introduction to research and theory on the development and changes in perception, cognition, emotion, and social functioning across the life span. Focus on birth through adulthood. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Developmental Psychology
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. Introduction to the scientific study of psychoactive drugs (e.g., drugs that affect the mind). Drug use in modern society and the basic neurobiology related to neurotransmission and drug effects. Pharmacological and neurobiological mechanisms of different classes of legal, illegal, and medicinal drugs, including alcohol, caffeine, tobacco, stimulants, depressants, anti-depressants, pain-killers, and hallucinogens. Common misconceptions, drug effects, addiction, medical use of marijuana, and America's drug policies. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Sex, Evolution, and Human Nature
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
short_title: Mental Lives of Babies and An...
title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
subject: PSYC

description: Offered Online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Autism and Related Disorders
subject: PSYC

description: An introduction to Islam. Topics include Muhammad and the Qur'an; Muslim tradition and religious law; Islamic philosophy and theology; Shi'ism and Sufism; basic beliefs and practices of the Muslim community; religious institutions; and modern trends. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to Islam
subject: RLST

description: A survey of Western Europe from the late medieval period to the eighteenth century. Major topics include the Crusades, late medieval heretical movements, the Protestant and Catholic Reformations, the wars of religion, the seventeenth-century witch craze, and the rise of secularism and tolerance. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: From Crusade to Enlightnement: Medieval & Early Modern Europe
subject: RLST

description: The development of both theocratic and democratic ideals in modern Islamic political thought and the development of regimes of government in Muslim countries since the nineteenth century. Early constitutional movements, the rise of political Islam, the management of religion in various twentieth-century states, the Iranian revolution, and the growth of Salafi ideas, culminating in the ISIS caliphate. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Islam&DemocracyModMiddleEast
subject: RLST

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 & RUSS S242. Credit only on completion of RUSS S140. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,900. Course dates: May 30- July 26.

subject: RUSS

description: Five weeks in St. Petersburg (no language classes in New Haven). An intensive "language-abroad" course featuring study of Russian at the fourth year level. Students stay with a Russian family and receive language training (7 hours per week), further developing all four language skills and immediately putting them to practice during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 151. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S242. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 24 - July 31.
title: Fourth-Year Russian I
subject: RUSS

description: An in-depth examination of the great short works of two of Russia's most famous writers, Fyodor Dostoevsky and Leo Tolstoy, considered in their historical, cultural, and literary contexts. We will be reading Dostoevsky's White Nights, Notes from the Underground, A Gentle Creature, and The Dream of a Ridiculous Man; Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Ilych, The Kreutzer Sonata, Master and Man, and Father Sergius. Consideration of nineteenth-century Russian intellectual history, philosophy, and religious thought. Part of each class will be devoted to a discussion of writing skills and strategies. Readings and discussion in English. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Great Short Works of Dostoevsky and Tolstoy
subject: RUSS

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. Explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complimented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St.Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S150/151. Course dates: May 30 - July 26.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design and data interpretation, through lectures, reading and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions of preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition: $3,750. May 30 - July 29.
title: Scientific Research: Process and Presentation
subject: SCIE

description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Foundations of Modern Social Theory
subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation states. Mechanisms and challenges of incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Global Public Health
subject: SOCY

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. Overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 2 Credits. Tuition $7,300. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: SOCY

description: Systems of schooling as they maintain or alleviate inequality. Relationships among privilege, power, and schooling; links between schools and societal stratification; contributions of educational institutions to both social mobility and the preservation of the prevailing social order. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Race, Class, and Education
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and post-communist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,650. Course dates: July 4 - August 5.
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Valencia, Spain. A language program that explores historical and contemporary issues in Spanish culture. Set in Valencia, a city founded by the Romans 2000 years ago, this course aims to reflect on both Spanish ancient heritage and modernity. Key works of literature will foster discussion on a wide range of topics such as the environment, the Mediterranean trade, politics and religion. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Valencia, costs of room and board in Valencia, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: SPAN 140, 145, a score of 5 on the AP exam, a placement test score of L5 or equivalent. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Course dates: May 23 - June 24.
title: Language, Culture, and Society of Spain
subject: SPAN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven and 4 weeks in Lima, Peru. The historical, social, and cultural development of Peru from pre-Columbian times to the present. Peruvian history; the culture and character of Peru and of its capital, Lima; architecture, art, gastronomic history, immigration, and ethnicity. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from site, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.
title: Cultural Studies of Peru
subject: SPAN

description: 4 weeks in New Haven, 4 weeks in Bilbao. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from site, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.

subject: SPAN

description: An introduction to statistical reasoning. Topics include controlled experiments and observational studies; histograms and scatterplots, averages and standard deviations; measurement error, the normal approximation; correlation and regression; probability and chance variation; sampling, the Gallup Poll and Current Population Survey; tests of significance. Focus on understanding concepts rather than mathematical manipulation. No formal mathematical prerequisite. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Introduction to Statistics
subject: STAT

description: An exploration of the ideas and forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Seminar topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Seminar members actively participate in games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Introduction to the Study of the City
subject: STCY

description: Offered in Tanzania. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Credit only on completion of SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Tanzania. Students are responsible for arranging travel and paying for airfare to and from Arusha, as well as passport, visa, inoculations, and similar expenses. For further information visit the Study Abroad program page. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: May 30 - July 22.

subject: SWAH

Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Tanzania, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: February 15. Enrollment limited. subject: SWAH

description: Twentieth-century British theater history as examined through the prism of a seminal, unique and revolutionary generation of actors: John Gielgud, Edith Evans, Sybil Thorndike, Laurence Olivier, Ralph Richardson, Michael Redgrave, Peggy Ashcroft and Alec Guinness. In listening to recordings and studying written accounts and films of their stage performances, we will uncover the ways in which this group of eight influenced and made possible the work of leading playwrights and critics and changed the face of international theater.
title: The Actor's Role in 20th Century British Theater History
subject: THST

description: Study of drama, performance, and dance-theater created in the last ten years, with special attention to works produced in 2013 and 2014. Readings from both published and unpublished American and British plays, contemporary criticism, interviews, and essays by the artists themselves. Video of works created by companies such as Elevator Repair Service, Les Freres Corbusier, and the Nature Theater of Oklahoma. Will include attendance of productions in and around New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Theater Now
subject: THST

description: Offered Online. In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. For college students and beyond. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Technology fee: $85. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: THST

description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to the Peabody Museum, the Yale Farm, and the Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Women, Food and Culture
subject: WGSS

description: Why do we have sex? Sex has been a central concern to anthropologists since the very founding of the discipline in the late 19th century. This course analyzes the various aspects of sex from the perspective of sociocultural anthropology and linguistic anthropology. Topics include: sexual morphology and behavior; constructions of sex and gender; gendered violence, power, and language; and kinship and mating. Course readings will draw broadly from both historical and contemporary work within the broad discipline of anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,750. Session B: July 4 - August 5.
title: Anthropoligical Approaches to Sex
subject: WGSS

description: This course offers a survey of girls' comics, or shojo manga, in Japan. We will discuss major historical trends, read works by important artists, watch adaptations (including anime and live-action TV series/films)and analyze gender and sexuality within the texts as well as in the manga industry. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,750. Session A: May 30 - July 1.
title: Girls' Manga and Gender/Sexuality in Japan
subject: WGSS
